text:
York Avenue (at time shown, Avenue A), east side, from 63rd to 64th Streets, and east of the Avenue to 67th Street, showing Rockefeller
Institute.
The American Malting Company plant (formerly Neidlingler, Schmidt & Company), from 63rd to 64th Streets, will later pass into the hands of George Ehret's brewing company, and finally be demolished
in October 1930.
The buildings of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (incorporated 1V01) are shown as follows in this picture: The chimney of the new power house, just completed on the N.W. corner of Exterior Street (Marie Curie Avenue since 1935) and 64th Street, shows above the malting plant in the foreground. Then comes the Main Hospital, built about 1909, its long axis nearly in line with 65th Street (which is not cut through east of the Avenue). Then the original laboratory, dedicated May 11, 1906, stands facing 66th Street and the Avenue. To the left of the picture Laboratory No. 2 is shown under construction, and behind it the chimney of
the original power house built in 1906.
In the right background, through b3rd Street, may be seen the East River, Blackwell's (now Welfare) Island, and Queens. This part of Avenue A, north of 59th Street, will not be called York Avenue till
late in 1928.
Early 1916.

(1)
Flower Surgical Hospital, and New York Homeopathic College, York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), west side, from 63rd to 64th Streets. This hospital was built here in 1890, except the building on the 64th Street corner, which went up around 1902 or a little
later.
August 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a bit over a year later. The clearing in the right foreground is the site of the old Ehret malting plant, which
has just been demolished.
December 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Flower Surgical Hospital, and New York Homeopathic College, York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), west side, from 63rd to 64th Streets. This hospital was built here in 1890, except the building on the 64th Street corner, which went up around 1902 or a little
later.
August 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a bit over a year later. The clearing in the right foreground is the site of the old Ehret malting plant, which
has just been demolished.
December 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue, west side, south from 64th Street, showing the New York Homeopathic College, and the Flower Hospital on the N.W. corner of 63rd Street, then the Consolidated Gas tanks, and the
garage from 61st to 60th Streets.
64th Street will later be closed east of York Avenue.
August 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

501-517 East 63rd Street, at, adjoining, and east of the N.E. corner of York Avenue. The large building in the background is the George Ehret Brewery.
October 20, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), east side, at 63rd Street, showing the Burns Brothers coal yard (which is to be removed) on the S.E. corner and the George Ehret halting plant (once the American Malting Company) in the 63rd to 64th Streets block. Demolition of the latter has already begun. The apparent closeness of the grain elevator is due only to the angle of the camera. Compare this with the view of this block about 1913.
October 20, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

New York Homeopathic College and Flower Hospital, York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), west side, from 64th to 63rd Streets, from the clearing on the east side where the old malting plant has been demolished. The Flower Surgical Hospital, on the 63rd Street side, was opened by the Homeopathic College in 1890; and the other two buildings were erected about the same time.
December 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, seen from 64th Street east of York Avenue. This block of 64th Street, east of York Avenue, which now forms the southern entrance to Exterior Street (Marie Curie Avenue), will later be permanently closed and fenced off with the malting house lot to the left, after Marie Curie Avenue has been extended down to 63rd Street.
December 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

New York Homeopathic College and Flower Hospital, York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), west side, from 64th to 63rd Streets, from the clearing on the east side where the old malting plant has been demolished. The Flower Surgical Hospital, on the 63rd Street side, was opened by the Homeopathic College in 1890; and the other two buildings were erected about the same time.
December 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, seen from 64th Street east of York Avenue. This block of 64th Street, east of York Avenue, which now forms the southern entrance to Exterior Street (Marie Curie Avenue), will later be permanently closed and fenced off with the malting house lot to the left, after Marie Curie Avenue has been extended down to 63rd Street.
December 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue (formerly Avenue A), east side, north from 63rd Street, showing the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, on the grounds from 64th to 68th Streets, and the new New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College, beginning at 68th Street where Jones' Wood Coliseum and Washington Park used to be prior to 1890. The Rockefeller Center dedicated its first building, the one in the center of the group, in May 1906. The new New York Hospital is nearing completion. In the foreground, the lot from 63rd to 64th Streets is shown fenced off, but 64th Street is still open east of York Avenue. -June 30, 1931. P.L. Sperr NO REPRODUCTIONS

York Ave., north from East 63rd Street. Shown on the right, is the
Cornell University Medical College and affilaites.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
York Ave., west side, north from and including East 63rd., to and including 64th Streets, as seen across Marie Curie Ave. Buildings shown form
the Flower Hospital.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
York Ave., west side, north from and including East 63rd., to and including 64th Streets, as seen across Marie Curie Ave. Buildings shown form
the Flower Hospital.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue, west side, from East 63rd to 64th Streets, showing the old Flower Hospital buildings prior to demolition by the Mutual Life Insnrance Company, as owner. This property extends 4bout 380 feet west of the Avenue on both streets and provides aites for 11 buildings. Activities are to be continued at the Fifth Avenue Hospital at Fifth Avenue and East
105th Street.
December 31, 1939
Gift of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library

York Avenue, north from East 63rd Street. Shown on the left is the cleared site of the former Flower Hospital. To the right is the massive pile housing the Cornell Medical College-New York Hospital Center.
September 29, 1940
No's. 1o2
P. L. Sperr

York Avenue, north from East 63rd Street. Shown on the left is the cleared site of the former Flower Hospital. To the right is the massive pile housing the Cornell Medical College-New York Hospital Center.
September 29, 1940
No's. 1o2
P. L. Sperr

York Avenue, west side, from East 63rd to 64th Street's, showing the cleared site of the former Flower Hospital. At the right is the private pavillion and
which will shortly follow.
April 28, 1940
0ift of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Lbrary

York Avenue, west side, from East 63rd (left) to 64th Streets showing demolition of the New York Homoeopathic College and Haspital buildings. The units constituting Flower Hospital have fallen, leaving the nurses home and annex on 63rd Street and the private pavillion at 64th Street corner to follow. Continuation of this institution's activities will be conducted at the Fifth Avenue Hospital (105th to 106th Street's).
April 28, 1940
Gift of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library

York Avenue, west side, from East 63rd to 64th Streets, showing the cleared site of the tormer Flower Hospital. The apartments appearing to the right are on the north side of East 64th Street and extend westward to First
Avenue.
September 29, 1940
No's. 1-2
P. L. Sperr

York Avenue, west side, from East 63rd to 64th Streets, showing the cleared site of the tormer Flower Hospital. The apartments appearing to the right are on the north side of East 64th Street and extend westward to First
Avenue.
September 29, 1940
No's. 1-2
P. L. Sperr

York Avenue, west side, south from East 64th to 63rd Streets, showing the old Flower Hospital buildings under demolition. The intact structure at the S.W. corner of 64th Street is the private pavillion. This is to be included. At the left is a gas holder of the Consolidated
Gas Company.
April 28, 1940
Gift of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library
